title: Create a Backup of This Repository
body: We should create a backup of the repository on the KTH github. It is important to find a way of copying the issues over, the code base is easy to replicate.

title: Create testLang to Properly Test MAL Languages
body:
We should create a separate language called testLang used to for the tests.

This language could be used to explore corner cases and more easily evaluate features in the language and attack graph.

For example, coreLang, does not currently have any subtype operators which means that it is no longer being tested.

Set operations and the transitive operator are also known to have bugs and not be tested sufficiently.

title: Standardize order of imports
body:
For the order of imports we can standardize what goes first with isort in CI and sticking to a convention.

_Originally posted by @nkakouros in https://github.com/mal-lang/mal-toolbox/pull/53#discussion_r1637095298_

title: Some dosctrings end with a period, others don't.
body:
Some dosctrings end with a period, others don't. Enabling Ruff (or some other linter if Ruff does not cover such stuff) would help keep the format consistent throughout.

_Originally posted by @nkakouros in https://github.com/mal-lang/mal-toolbox/pull/53#discussion_r1637107667_

title: Decide which values should be optional or not in dataclasses and initializers
body:
Some values (id, name, ..) are optional and default to None in dataclasses that we have and also initializers.
Example: 
- AttackerAttachment has several optionals set to None per default
- AttackGraphNode has many optionals

We should go through the code and decide which should be optional and not.

title: Type hint the compiler
body:
Compiler currently not type hinted in #44 (PR #53) and we ignore it when running mypy.
Type hint the code and make sure it passes mypy checks.

title: Check for duplicate associations
body:
Raise exceptions if a user tries to add duplicate or invalid associations

- [x] Add type->associations mapping to Model (for faster lookup)
- [x] Check that added associations are unique
- [x] Check that asset lists (fields) in associations don't contain duplicate assets
- [x] Check that association connections between single assets are unique from previously added associations
- [x] Tests
- [x] Some renaming

title: A way to add custom metadata to Model
body:
We want to have a way to add custom metadata to a Model in MAL Toolbox.

Idea: Add instance variable metadata that is initialized in __init__ to:
```python

self.metadata = {
            'name': self.name,
            'langVersion': self.lang_classes_factory.lang_graph.metadata['version'],
            'langID': self.lang_classes_factory.lang_graph.metadata['id'],
            'malVersion': '0.1.0-SNAPSHOT',
            'MAL-Toolbox Version': __version__,
            'info': 'Created by the mal-toolbox model python module.'
        }

```

This was Akash or anyone who wants to can add metadata through model.metadata[<fieldname>] = value
Note: must also be exported in to_dict and loaded in from_dict.

title: Check for Duplicate Associations
body: When adding an association to the model there should be a check that evaluates if that association is already part of the model, either as part of the same association grouping or individual association.

title: Bug: new_dep_chain in LanguageGraph.reverse_dep_chain referenced before definition

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
new_dep_chain in LanguageGraph.reverse_dep_chain referenced before definition


```python
    case 'subType':
        result_reverse_chain = self.reverse_dep_chain(
            new_dep_chain.next_link, # BUG: new_dep_chain undefined
            reverse_chain
        )
        new_dep_chain = DependencyChain(
            type = 'subtype',
            next_link = result_reverse_chain
        )
        new_dep_chain.subtype = dep_chain.subtype
        return new_dep_chain

```

Should not be referenced before definition, indicates some sort of bug

title: Attack Graph and Language Graph Do Not Handle 'Collect' Step Expression Correctly

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
Both the language graph and attack graph generation incorrectly handle the 'collect' step expression correctly and apply the right hand to all of the assets on the left hand collectively instead of individually resolving it against each one.

This is an issue especially when dealing with intersection and difference operators where the results may be incorrect.

Example: `(a.field1 /\ a.field2)` should be different to `a.(field1 /\ field2)`.

title: Optimize lookups with dicts instead of lists

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
Everywhere where we use next() on lists to fetch assets/nodes/objects by name/id/something else we could use dict lookups instead to decrease time complexity to O(1) instead of O(n),

It should be done in all parts of the code where we search for objects by some attribute and where it is possible and sane to change it into a dict lookup. E.g. LanguageGraph, AttackGraph, perhaps model if not already solved.

title: Deletes securicad.py and specification.py
body:
This PR builds on #45 and #43 (only the last commit in this PR is new). 

If these 2 PRs get merged, then if securicad.py is gone, specification.py is not used anymore.

securicad.py is unmaintained. It also does more than what is needed to parse securicad files. If parsing such files is still needed, we can write a **much** simpler transpiler that converts the securicad model format to our own model format.

title: Fixes subType expression parsing
body:
The `specification.extends_asset` method is expecting asset names as input while the attack graph uses LanguageGraphAsset objects. 

If this gets merged, `specification.extends_asset` will be used only in securicad.py which is outdated anyway.

title: Remove unused function from neo4j.py
body: I couldn't find `get_model` being used anywhere.

title: Models with a common name between associations and assets are not supported

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body: A model file that shares names between two associations or an association and an asset will make `Model.load_from_file` fail. The issue is that the wrong entity (asset, association) is selected by json schema objects to initialize the association.

title: Implement _from_dict for LanguageGraph

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
Model and AttackGraph can be created from yaml/json through _from_dict, but LanguageGraph lacks this functionality and can currently only be created from .mal/.mar.

We would like this feature for consitency and being able to edit LanguageGraphs and load them again, but it is not high priority.

title: Improve Handling of  TTC Values
body: The current handling of TTC values is very limited. We should have a look at ways of improving this, especially when it comes to the analyzers.

title: Cleanup the Current Model Format
body: Some of the old conventions from the old format that was used with securiCAD are still present. We should remove them to keep the format clearer.

title: Add pattern matching module for querying Model
body:
- We want  to be able to query for 'patterns' in AttackGraph, LanguageGraph and Model (this issue is for Model)
- It should be possible to query for a pattern, this means to find a 'chain' of assets with certain properties and associations 
- Example of pattern: "Find the chain starting with an asset of type X connected through an association of type Y to a chain of assets ending up in an asset of type Z with property P" -> should return the assets (?)

We might also want to be able to combine patterns from different types of graphs (e.g. Auth->FullAccess in AttackGraph where the asset in the Model is connected to somethingsomething). Keep this in mind during design.

For this issue:
- [ ] Create patterns module for Model
- [ ] Make it possible to query the Model with a pattern and return matching assets (regex like)
- [ ] Tests

title: Add pattern matching module for querying LanguageGraph
body:
- We want  to be able to query for 'patterns' in AttackGraph, LanguageGraph and Model (this issue is for LanguageGraph)
- It should be possible to query for a pattern, this means to find certain types of nodes structured in a specified way

We might also want to be able to combine patterns from different types of graphs. Keep this in mind during design.

For this issue:
- [ ] Create patterns module for LanguageGraph
- [ ] Make it possible to query the LanguageGraph with a pattern and return matching nodes (regex like)
- [ ] Tests

title: Add pattern matching module for querying AttackGraph
body:
- We want  to be able to query for 'patterns' in AttackGraph, LanguageGraph and Model (this issue is for AttackGraph)
- It should be possible to query for a pattern, this means to find certain types of nodes structured in a specified way
- Patterns (for AttackGraph) would be on format "give me a chain of nodes that start with 'nodetype 1 with only parent that is x' and end with 'nodetype 2 with at least one parent and in between there must be a node of type x that has property y'". Think regex.
- Example: In the AttackGraph find redundant/superfluous attack steps like AttemptRead -> successfulRead -> Read (this can be used to combine/compress them)
- Other example: In AttackGraph find nodes with single credentials in the graph (can be used to suggest 2FA)
- Other example: In AttackGraph find paths from Auth->FullAccess

We might also want to be able to combine patterns from different types of graphs (e.g. Auth->FullAccess in AttackGraph where the asset in the ModelInstance is connected to somethingsomething). Keep this in mind during design.

For this issue:
- [ ] Design the solution
- [ ] Create patterns module for AttackGraph
- [ ] Make it possible to query the module to find patterns in AttackGraph and return chain of nodes
- [ ] Tests

title: Remove firstSteps attack step from the attack graph
body: There is no reason to keep the firstSteps attack step in the attack graph since it is not used by anyone and it is just messing with the observation space of the mal-simulator agents.

title: Add profiling
body: Add optional profiling to the relevant modules so that we can evaluate performance when necessary.

title: Explore ways of having optional package dependencies

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
Try to sort out a better way of having option requirements for the project.

Right now py2neo should only be required if Neo4j is relevant and the pytest package should also be optional. We may be able to have installation flags that determine exactly which packages need to be installed.

title: Fix bug when unpacking transitive non-field expressions

milestone.title: Future Planning
milestone.description: A milestone that all future work ideas can be assigned to.

body:
Apparently there is a bug when unpacking transitive step expressions that recur  over non-fields. This was discovered when @nkakouros was working on the new MAL compiler, but I no longer recall what the exact issue was.

Update the description once an investigations has started.

title: Explore Different Visualization Alternatives
body:
The current Neo4j python package has reached End-of-Life.

It is worth investigating if other visualization tools are available that better suit our needs.

title: Use the LanguageGraph to generate the AttackGraph
body:
Currently, the AttackGraph is generated using a lang dict and a model dict. The lang dict is the JSON representation of the mal spec as produced by the compiler. If, instead, the LanguageGraph object that corresponds to the lang dict was used, the code would be simplified. To make this look nice, some changes in the LanguageGraph would also be required, mainly converting lists to dicts. But I believe it would result in a nicer API to work with.

For example, in the following lines:

https://github.com/mal-lang/mal-toolbox/blob/48faad5c1849afa0118b513e5c7caff819283e6f/maltoolbox/attackgraph/attackgraph.py#L370-L375

the `get_attacks_for_class` function could be removed completely, and instead we could do the following:

```python
attack_steps = lang_graph.assets[asset].attack_steps
```

Having the language graph available in the attack graph would also facilitate the implementation of things like obtaining each node's asset type (which can still be done now but in a rigid way; through looping the lang dict, not having fully-qualified attack names, etc.).

title: Mal compiler improvements
body:
- [ ] Improve cli experience, perhaps use docopt
    - [ ] Specify file paths
- [ ] If category name contains a dot, the compiler breaks badly

title: Analyzer/Checker draft
body:
# Analyzer/Checker draft

This is a draft for the analyzer/checker described in issue #6   
Only some of the checks are implemented into this version. 

## Implementation
The analyzer is a parent to the compiler `mal_visitor.py`.   
For every visit state we define inside `mal_visitor.py`, we also define inside `mal_analyzer.py` (if we want to check it). We can then access the `mal_analyzer.py` visit-method via super(...).
To make the code more readable there is a `decoration`  class inside `malAnalyzer` that will implement the super(...) code into the original visit method and also trigger an error if the method isn't defined inside `mal_analyzer.py `.

`ParseTreeVisitor` method `visit` is overridden in order to preform a `post-analysis` as the last step. `post-analysis` is for checks where we need to iterate all the assets or similar collections of data. By using the visit method to trigger `post-analysis` we don't need to change how the compiler is used. 

With this implementation it is very easy to add new rules to analyze/check and the core compiler only needs to add one line of code for every new `visitor` that should be checked.

## Naming

- Use the name `analyzer` or `checker`?
- Call the last step `post-analysis`?

## Potential issues / changes

- The `visit` method in `mal_analyser` is doing more then the method is meant to do, which can lead to confusion.
- The `Analyze` decoration can be removed in order to use super(...).visit(...) instead. Downside is no warnings for non-existing super methods.
- Don't have `malAnalyzer ` as parent to `malVisitor`, we could make `malAnalyzer` as a "normal" class and then preform calls in every visit function instead. 
- Some of the methods should be refactored.
